Award.AwardTitle: EFRI 2-DARE: Scalable Growth and Fabrication of Anti-Ambipolar Heterojunction Devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
Communications systems such as WiFi, GPS, wireless sensor networks, and radio frequency electronics are critical to the nation?s infrastructure and have had a transformative impact on daily life. However, existing applications of wireless technologies are often limited by the power consumption and speed of the underlying electronic switches, or transistors, that send and receive signals. Furthermore, current classes of transistors must be integrated into complex circuits to perform simple functions. This award supports the fundamental research necessary to make new classes of transistors that can improve the performance of existing communications technologies and open up new applications by enabling simplified circuit designs on flexible substrates. The development of inexpensive and scalable approaches to new transistor materials will facilitate the incorporation of these devices into new technologies. Computer models of novel transistors and communications circuits will be shared with industry partners to facilitate the transfer of knowledge and capabilities to industry, growing the high-tech economy. Outreach programs including cooperation with the Chicago Museum of Science and Industry will recruit a broad group of young people to careers in science and technology crucial to the nation?s economy and defense.

The objective of the proposed work is to create, characterize, understand, and exploit new classes of electronic and optoelectronic devices by integrating promising two-dimensional monolayer transition metal dichalcogenides with other low dimensional semiconductors including p-type organic semiconductors, sorted semiconducting single walled carbon nanotubes, and other two-dimensional materials. The project will fabricate novel ultrathin p-n heterojunctions of mixed dimensionality that exhibit unique and quantitatively advantageous properties arising from gate transparency and flexibility, and characterize the devices with advanced scanned probe techniques in addition to conventional current and capacitance versus voltage measurements. Custom chemical precursors will be designed and synthesized with the goal of achieving scalable growth and fabrication of ultrathin dichalcogenides by atomic layer deposition over large areas at reduced temperatures. To understand how the device physics leads to new properties and circuit performance, phenomenological models will be integrated into industry accepted nanodevice simulators, and a compact model will be developed. The fundamental knowledge and predictive models of ultrathin heterojunctions will expand engineering frontiers through quantitative understanding of charge transport, the demonstration of novel device characteristics, such as the recently discovered anti-ambipolar behavior, and the exploitation of these behaviors to create novel electronic circuits on flexible substrates with simpler designs and fewer elements than conventional unipolar field effect transistor-based circuits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Materials made from combinations of transition metals such as molybdenum and tungsten and chalcogenide elements such as sulfur and selenium naturally adopt a two-dimensional (2D) layered structure. These layers can be peeled apart and put back together in different combinations to make electronic devices that behave differently than conventional semiconductor devices made from silicon or gallium arsenide. Novel properties arise both from the extreme thinness of 2D materials and their arrangement with respect to metallic contacts and insulating dielectrics. This research project explored the novel properties of electronic devices made assemblies of 2D semiconductors with different electrical characteristics. The project advanced nanoscale electronics in three important ways. First, it developed new ways to synthesize and deposit 2D materials that can be scaled up by industry. Second, it demonstrated new types of device and circuit behaviors that enable new and more efficient approaches to applications such as neuromorphic, or brain-like, computing. Third, it developed new understanding of how physics in devices made from 2D materials leads to new properties and circuit performance, and embedded this understanding in computer models that are used by industry to advance microelectronics technology.

 

The intellectual merit of the work encompasses advances in three major thrust areas: understanding how to harness the geometry of 2D materials in devices to realize novel output characteristics; the development of chemical precursors and processes for large area synthesis; and incorporating the physics of 2D materials and their interfaces into computational models. The project developed novel approaches to fabricating ultrathin vertical junctions between p-type and n-type materials with tunable output characteristics, and showed that an anti-ambipolar response function enables more complex functions to be realized in simpler circuits compared to conventional technology. Key to this capability is the scientific understanding of how vertical and lateral regions of devices are influenced by external electric fields, and contribute differently to device characteristics. Both solution and vapor phase processing methods were developed to make 2D materials over large areas so that circuits can be fabricated. The ability to insert different 2D materials into ultrathin devices resulted in the achievement of tunable Gaussian-like anti-ambipolar response, which was used to emulate functions carried out by neurons. Physical insights into operating principles were gained using simulations based on first principles methods to enable subsequent prediction of 2D materials based device behavior.

 

The broader impacts of the work included the development of new capabilities for the microelectronics industry and outreach to promote public awareness of the potential for 2D materials in future electronics. The development of new chemical precursors for low-temperature atomic layer deposition of transition metal dichalcogenides enables the patterning of 2-D materials and devices at large length scales using industry-standard lithography methods. The new types of semiconductor heterojunctions demonstrated in 2D materials produced by scalable methods provide opportunities for device engineers to design output characteristics not exhibited by conventional electronic devices. In turn, circuit designers have new functions at their disposal, and may envision architectures that could take advantage of the unique functionality. For example, the ability to tune Gaussian anti-ambipolar output characteristics provide an efficient means to emulate brain-like computing in simple circuits. The scientific findings concerning the properties of 2D materials and their interfaces have contributed to the refinement of NEMO-5, a freely available software tool that is extensively used by industry. Thus, the project findings can be leveraged by industry to develop new electronic technologies. Towards broader public awareness of the potential impact of 2D materials, a museum exhibit on carbon and two-dimensional materials that was developed in partnership with the Chicago Museum of Science and Industry was displayed at the Chicago O'Hare International Airport.
